awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Virus Infection and Immune Responses: Modeling, Analysis, and Implications
awd_abstract_narration:
The objectives of this project are to develop and analyze mathematical models to quantitatively investigate virus infection and immune responses and to demonstrate their implications for antiviral treatment and vaccination. Mathematical models, validated and informed by experimental data, have made important contributions to the understanding of interactions between virus, cells, and immune responses. However, new data emerge and update our understanding of the biology underlying these processes. Sometimes the analysis of new data generates conflicting results. This project will develop and analyze new models, compare them with experimental data, explain potential discrepancies generated by new data, and address the implications to therapy and vaccine development. The first part of this project develops multi-scale models to study hepatitis C virus (HCV) dynamics in patients treated with new antiviral drugs. These models include both intracellular viral replication and extracellular cell infection. The second part of the project develops comprehensive immune models to elucidate the mechanisms in controlling HIV, a virus that causes AIDS in humans. The modeling predictions will be compared with experimental data to determine the relative roles of target cell availability and specific immune mechanisms in viral control.
 
This project will generate modeling, computational, and data analysis methods in quantitative studies of virus infection and immune responses. The multi-scale virus models will establish a theoretical framework for studying viral dynamics in patients treated with new drugs and will investigate the emergence of drug resistance. This can help to develop more effective combination therapy and improve cure rates. Such combination strategies have achieved a great success in the management of HIV infection. The comprehensive immune models developed in this project will address fundamental questions in immunology, e.g.,  how the immune system controls viral load and why some monkeys can live with an HIV-like virus without progressing to AIDS. The results may suggest effective strategies for the development of future virus vaccines and immune-based therapies. This interdisciplinary research will provide extensive training opportunities to students from diverse backgrounds at levels from high school to graduate school.  This project includes extensive collaborations with experimentalists which will provide mathematics students with a broad range of training opportunities in the biomedical field. The interdisciplinary collaboration will also help to improve the dissemination of the project's results to a broad scientific audience.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

The overall research goal of this project is to develop and analyze data-driven mechanistic models to quantitatively investigate virus infection and immune responses, and demonstrate their implications for antiviral treatment and vaccination. The grant has led to 53 publications. Many are published in top journals of mathematical biology and applied mathematics. Some important results are summarized below.

1. HIV persistence. HIV can persist in patients despite long-term treatment. The PI proposed mechanisms, tested by models and data, to explain low HIV persistence. The results suggest that treatment intensification or activation therapy may not help eradicate latent infection. Blocking the proliferation of latently infected cells might be a good way. See publications in SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics 2017, Journal of Theoretical Biology 2014, Bulletin of Mathematical Biology 2019 and Journal of Theoretical Biology 2017.

2. Immune cell depletion. The progressive depletion of CD4+ T cells (target of HIV infection) is the hallmark of HIV infection but the mechanism underlying the slow decline remains unknown. The PI developed a model to describe the process of pyroptosis, a form of programmed cell death, and showed that it can explain the long-term CD4+ T cell decline. The finding suggests that a combination of current treatment and caspase-1 inhibitor that inhibits pyroptosis might provide a new way to maintain the immune cell population. See publication in PLoS Computational Biology 2015.

3. Treatment effectiveness. Viral decay dynamics may depend on the inhibited stages of the viral life cycle. We developed a model incorporating multiple infection stages and various drug classes that interfere with specific stages of the viral life cycle. The work provides a quantitative and systematic comparison of the effect of different drug classes on HIV decay dynamics. This finding may help develop optimal combination of available HIV drugs to reduce the time needed for viral reduction to below the detection limit. See publications in Bulletin of Mathematical Biology 2016.

4. Macrophage infection and multiple infection. Besides CD4+ T cells, HIV can also infect macrophages. We showed that even when CD4 infection is completely blocked by therapy, virus can still persist in macrophages. Thus, improving drug efficacies in heterogeneous target cells is crucial for achieving HIV eradication. Multiple infection of target cells by HIV can lead to viral escape from host immune responses and drug resistance to drugs. We found that cell-to-cell transmission plays a critical role in forming HIV multiple infection and thus has important implications for HIV evolution and pathogenesis. See publications in Journal of Mathematical Biology 2020 and Journal of Theoretical Biology 2021.

5. Coupled dynamics of HIV infection. Most of the modeling studies investigated the control of HIV infection at either within-host or between-host level. However, the optimal treatment strategy for the individual may not be optimal for the population and vice versa. Whether early initiation of therapy can bring benefits to HIV-infected patients in the large population level remains controversial. We developed a synergistic treatment protocol that is beneficial to both HIV-infected individuals and the whole population. We showed that early treatment initiation could decrease the number of both total and drug-resistant HIV incidence. High pre-exposure prophylaxis with earlier antiretroviral treatment would provide the greatest benefit. See publications in Proceedings of the Royal Society 2017, BMC Medicine 2018 and Mathematical Biosciences 2019.

6. COVID-19 and others. The PI has worked on the within-host dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 infection, COVID-19 transmission and control, the influence of mask wearing and vaccination, and the risk of business reopening during the pandemic. He also extended the modeling efforts to other infectious diseases, such as Zika, HPV, etc. See publications in Mathematical Biosciences 2020, International Journal of Infectious Diseases 2020, Frontiers in Applied Mathematics and Statistics 2020, Mathematical Biosciences and Engineering 2020 and Journal of Biological Dynamics 2020.

Broader impacts

The grant has supported the training of 10 graduate students (6 PhD students and 5 of them are female), 2 postdocs, and 6 undergrad students. The PI also supervised a few high school students and one got the third place in the Michigan State Science Fair. The grant led to publications with undergraduate and high school students. In addition to two new courses developed based on the results, the PI has been actively involved in various research programs for students at different levels. He organized two conferences and many sessions in other conferences. He is the recipient of several awards and was interviewed by various media, which conveyed the results to the general audience. The PI served on panels on career development for junior researchers. He has delivered many talks/lectures in conferences, seminars, colloquia, and summer programs. A recent series of lectures was given in the Summer School of Math Biology at Nepal in June 2019, supported by CIMPA, an association with the mission to promote research in math in developing countries.
